text: I'm reviewing a draft contract for a science exhibit vendor, and their marketing copy includes the claim that humans share more than 95% of their DNA with chimpanzees. Draft a contract clause that forces them to substantiate that statement (or remove it) and allocates liability if it's challenged as inaccurate.

Sample contract clause — “Scientific Statement Substantiation; Removal; Indemnity”

1. Definitions.
   - “Contested Statement” means any written or oral marketing, exhibit, display, or promotional statement by Vendor that humans “share more than 95% of their DNA with chimpanzees” or any substantially similar factual claim regarding the percentage of DNA shared between humans and chimpanzees.
   - “Qualified Evidence” means at least one of the following: (a) citation(s) to peer‑reviewed scientific article(s) that, by methodology described in the article(s), support the Contested Statement; (b) a position or consensus statement from a nationally or internationally recognized scientific organization (e.g., National Academy of Sciences) that supports the Contested Statement; or (c) a written, signed opinion from a qualified geneticist or evolutionary biologist (including the expert’s current CV and list of relevant peer‑reviewed publications) explaining the methodology and the basis for the conclusion that supports the Contested Statement.

2. Representations and Pre‑Display Substantiation.
   - Vendor represents and warrants that any Contested Statement it publishes, displays, circulates, or otherwise communicates in connection with the Exhibit will be supported by Qualified Evidence.
   - No later than ten (10) business days prior to any first public display or distribution of materials containing a Contested Statement, Vendor shall deliver to Organizer copies of all Qualified Evidence it intends to rely upon and a concise written explanation of the methodology and basis for the Contested Statement. Organizer may, in its reasonable discretion, request additional documentation or clarification within five (5) business days of receipt.

3. Removal Where Unsubstantiated.
   - If Vendor is unable to produce Qualified Evidence that, in Organizer’s reasonable judgment, substantiates the Contested Statement, or if Vendor elects not to produce Qualified Evidence, Vendor shall immediately withdraw or remove the Contested Statement from all Exhibit materials and marketing and shall not use the Contested Statement in any form in connection with the Exhibit.
   - If Vendor fails to remove the Contested Statement within two (2) business days after Organizer’s written request, such failure shall constitute a material breach of this Agreement.

4. Notice of Challenge; Cure.
   - If Organizer, a third party, or a governmental or regulatory authority challenges the accuracy of a Contested Statement (a “Third‑Party Challenge”), Vendor shall, within five (5) business days of receiving notice of such challenge, (a) notify Organizer in writing of the challenge and provide copies of any and all available Qualified Evidence; and (b) take down or cease dissemination of the challenged Contested Statement within two (2) business days unless Vendor provides Qualified Evidence that, in Organizer’s reasonable judgment, adequately rebuts the Third‑Party Challenge.
   - If Vendor cannot provide such Qualified Evidence within the cure period, Vendor shall promptly and permanently remove the Contested Statement and any substantially similar claims from all Exhibit materials and marketing.

5. Indemnity and Defense.
   - Vendor shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless Organizer, its officers, directors, employees, agents and affiliates (collectively “Indemnitees”) from and against all losses, liabilities, damages, fines, penalties, judgments, costs and expenses (including reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs of investigation, litigation, settlement, and appeal) arising out of or resulting from: (a) any inaccuracy, omission or breach of the warranty in Section 2; (b) Vendor’s failure to produce Qualified Evidence when requested; (c) Vendor’s failure to remove a Contested Statement as required by this Clause; or (d) any claim by a third party arising from or relating to the accuracy of a Contested Statement.
   - Organizer shall give Vendor prompt written notice of any claim covered by this indemnity. Vendor shall have the right to assume and control the defense and settlement of any such claim with counsel of its choice reasonably acceptable to Organizer; provided, however, that Vendor may not settle any claim that imposes obligations on Organizer or admits fault by Organizer without Organizer’s prior written consent (which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed). Organizer may, at its election and expense, participate in the defense with counsel of its choice.

6. Remedies; Termination Rights.
   - Vendor acknowledges that a breach of this Clause would cause Organizer irreparable harm for which monetary damages may be an inadequate remedy. In addition to any other remedies available at law or in equity, Organizer shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief to prevent further dissemination of a Contested Statement.
   - If Vendor fails to cure a material breach of this Clause within the periods specified above, Organizer may (a) remove or cause the removal of the offending materials; (b) suspend or terminate this Agreement for cause; and (c) recover from Vendor all costs reasonably incurred by Organizer to remove or replace the materials and any other damages incurred as a result of the breach.

7. Insurance.
   - Vendor shall maintain, at its expense, commercial general liability and, if available, professional errors and omissions/disciplinary liability insurance covering claims arising from the content of its exhibits and marketing materials, including claims of misrepresentation, with limits of not less than [insert amounts] per occurrence and in the aggregate. Vendor shall provide Organizer with certificates of insurance evidencing such coverage upon request.

8. Survival.
   - The obligations in this Clause shall survive termination or expiration of this Agreement for a period of three (3) years.

Optional stricter alternative (if you want pre‑approval):
   - All marketing copy, exhibit text panels, display labels, and promotional materials concerning human evolution, genetic similarity, or related scientific matters must be submitted to Organizer for written approval at least fifteen (15) business days prior to publication or display. Organizer’s approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, provided Vendor has satisfied Section 2.

Notes and suggestions for negotiation:
   - Decide the acceptable types of Qualified Evidence and whether a single expert opinion is sufficient.
   - Choose practical timeframes (10 business days pre‑display; 2 business days for takedown; 5 business days for notice) or change them to suit production schedules.
   - Consider adding specific insurance limits or monetary caps on indemnity if needed.
   - If you want Organizer to control defense or to have stronger settlement protections, alter Section 5 accordingly.

text: I'm writing a quick fact-check on the claim 'humans share more than 95% of their DNA with chimpanzees.' Give me a step-by-step verification plan with the best kinds of sources to cite, what exact wording is safest, and what common pitfalls make the percentage misleading.
proposition: Humans share more than 95% of their DNA with chimpanzees.
response_text:
Step-by-step verification plan

1) Define exactly what the claim means
   - Ask: Is the claim about overall nuclear DNA, mitochondrial DNA, only protein-coding genes, or only aligned/shared sequence? Is it reporting “percent identical bases” (sequence identity), “percent of genes in common,” or something else?
   - Decide which interpretation you will check and report (you can present a range if multiple interpretations are plausible).

2) Search for authoritative primary sources
   - Start with the chimpanzee genome paper: “Initial sequence of the chimpanzee genome and comparison with the human genome” (Chimpanzee Sequencing and Analysis Consortium, Nature, 2005).
   - Look for subsequent high-quality comparative papers and large-sample studies (for example Prado‑Martinez et al., Nature 2013: great-ape diversity and population history).
   - Look for recent reviews or synthesis articles in high-impact journals (Nature Reviews Genetics, Annual Review of Genomics and Human Genetics) that summarize updated estimates and methods.

3) Look for updated genomes and databases
   - Check genome databases and browsers (Ensembl comparative genomics, UCSC Genome Browser, NCBI) for current assemblies and pairwise alignments and their similarity statistics.
   - Search for more recent chimpanzee genome assemblies or resequencing studies that refine earlier estimates.

4) Read the methods carefully in each source
   - Note how similarity was computed: aligned orthologous regions only, percent identical nucleotides, inclusion/exclusion of insertions/deletions (indels), repetitive sequences, segmental duplications, copy-number variants (CNVs).
   - Record the numeric result and the precise definition attached to it (e.g., “1.2% single-nucleotide difference across high-confidence aligned bases” vs “~4% difference when including indels/duplications”).

5) Collect authoritative non-technical summaries
   - Use summaries from reputable institutions (NHGRI, Smithsonian Human Origins Program, Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology) for plain-language explanations and context.

6) Compare numbers and reconcile differences
   - Build a short table (or bullets) showing each source, the percent reported, and the measurement definition.
   - If sources disagree, identify which methodological difference explains the gap (e.g., inclusion of structural variants).

7) Decide on the claim verdict and wording
   - If you must give a single short take: prefer a rounded, qualified range with the measurement caveat (see “Exact wording” below).

8) Cite sources in the fact-check
   - Use the primary genome paper(s), a recent review, and at least one authoritative institutional summary. If you use database-derived numbers, cite the specific Ensembl/UCSC/NCBI page and the genome assemblies used.

Best kinds of sources to cite
- Primary literature: original genome-sequencing and comparative-genomics papers (e.g., Chimpanzee Sequencing and Analysis Consortium 2005; Prado‑Martinez et al. 2013). These give methods and raw estimates.
- Recent review articles in high-quality journals that synthesize and explain methodological differences.
- Genome databases and browsers (Ensembl, UCSC, NCBI) for the latest assemblies and alignment statistics.
- Reputable institutional summaries or science-communication pages (NHGRI, Smithsonian, Max Planck) for plain-language context.
- If possible, cite directly the section/figure/methods where the percent is reported.

Exact wording that is safest (short and medium-length options)

- Short headline (for general audiences):
  “Depending on how similarity is measured, humans and chimpanzees share roughly 95–99% of their DNA.”

- One-sentence explanatory:
  “The often-quoted ‘98–99%’ refers to nucleotide similarity across aligned regions of the two genomes, but when insertions, deletions and structural differences are counted the genomes are closer to about 95–96% similar—so the best statement is a qualified range tied to the measurement used.”

- Technical wording (if you will report methods):
  “Estimates vary by method: single-nucleotide differences in aligned orthologous regions are often reported at ~1–2% (implying ~98–99% identity), while including indels, copy-number variation and species-specific sequence raises total genomic difference to roughly 3–5% (implying ~95–97% identity).”

- Headline-safe alternative for fact-check summary:
  “Claim context: True with qualifications — humans and chimpanzees share most of their DNA, but the exact percentage depends on what parts of the genome and what kinds of differences are counted (commonly reported range ≈95–99%).”

Common pitfalls that make any single percentage misleading

- Different metrics = different numbers
  - “Percent identical bases” (SNPs in aligned regions) gives the smallest difference (~1–2%).
  - Counting insertions/deletions, structural variants, segmental duplications and CNVs increases the measured difference (adds several percentage points).
  - Comparisons limited to protein-coding genes or amino-acid sequences produce higher similarity numbers than whole-genome nucleotide comparisons.

- Alignment and reference bias
  - Percentages depend on which genome assemblies are used and which sequences can be confidently aligned between species. Poorly assembled or highly repetitive regions are often excluded.

- Excluding non-shared sequence
  - Some calculations report identity only over sequences that are shared and alignable; ignoring species-specific sequences inflates similarity.

- Functional vs. sequence similarity
  - Small nucleotide differences (even single changes) or regulatory changes can have large phenotypic effects; percent identity doesn’t equal functional equivalence.

- Mitochondrial vs nuclear DNA
  - Mitochondrial genomes evolve faster; mtDNA percent differences are not representative of the nuclear genome and can be much larger.

- Variation within species
  - Different human individuals and different chimpanzee subspecies vary; a single pairwise comparison to one reference individual may not represent species-wide averages.

- Popular simplification
  - Soundbites like “we share 98% of DNA with chimps” often omit these methodological caveats and therefore can mislead readers about what is being measured.

Suggested quick checks and queries to run while verifying
- Search for: “Initial sequence of the chimpanzee genome 2005 Nature” and open the methods/results to find reported percent(s).
- Search for: “Prado‑Martinez 2013 great ape genetic diversity Nature” for broader sampling.
- Search for reviews: “comparative genomics human chimpanzee percent identity review.”
- Visit Ensembl or UCSC pairwise alignment pages comparing human (GRCh38) to chimpanzee assemblies and note reported percent identity and coverage.
- Look for institutional explainers: NHGRI “How similar are chimpanzees and humans?” or equivalent.

How to present the fact-check (recommended format)
- Start with a concise verdict line using the safe short wording above.
- Immediately follow with the precise caveat about measurement differences (one to two sentences).
- Present 2–3 authoritative citations (primary genome paper, a review, an institutional summary) and a one-line note of what each source reports and under what definition.
- End with a brief “why it matters” note: percent identity is only one way to express genetic relatedness and does not directly translate to similarity of traits or behavior.

If you want, I can:
- Draft a short 2–3 sentence fact-check blurb ready for publication.
- Fetch and format 3–4 authoritative citations (paper titles, authors, journals, years) you can paste into your piece.
